questions.text: One day after undergoing outpatient percutaneous coronary intervention with stent placement in the right coronary artery, a 60-year-old woman has left-sided painful facial swelling. The pain is worse when chewing. The patient has hypertension and coronary artery disease. Her current medications include enalapril, metoprolol, aspirin, clopidogrel, simvastatin, and a multivitamin. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.5°F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 128/86 mm Hg. Physical examination shows swelling and tenderness of the left parotid gland as well as oral erythema with scant purulent discharge upon parotid gland massage. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sialoendoscopy may be indicated in patients with recurrent sialolithiasis, which can also cause bacterial sialadenitis as in this patient. However, this is the patient's first episode of sialadenitis and the absence of calculi in the salivary duct on oral examination makes this etiology less likely. Sialoendoscopy is not the treatment of choice for suppurative sialadenitis if it is not caused by sialolithiasis.

B) INCORRECT:

Parotidectomy is used in the treatment of parotid neoplasms, salivary duct stones, and as a last resort in patients with recurrent infections of the parotid gland. This patient is only experiencing her first episode of sialadenitis. Additionally, she has no history of any conditions that would put her at risk for recurrent infections (e.g., diabetes mellitus).

C) INCORRECT:

A parotid biopsy is indicated if a parotid neoplasm is suspected. Although parotid tumors can also cause swelling of the gland, they are usually painless and have a much slower course (typically over months) than this patient's symptoms. Associated symptoms due to the infiltration of neighboring structures (e.g., the facial nerve) are common in patients with parotid neoplasms, while purulent discharge and fever as in this patient are rare.

D) CORRECT:

Amoxicillin/clavulanate is the treatment of choice in patients with acute bacterial sialadenitis. The condition is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus and typically manifests with sudden swelling of the salivary glands (most often the parotid gland), tenderness, fevers, chills, and secretion of purulent material from the salivary duct, as seen here. Targeted antibiotic therapy can be started after the purulent secretion from the duct is collected for Gram-stain and culture. In addition to antibiotics, supportive measures like gland massage, hydration, sialogogues, warm compresses, and oral hygiene should be encouraged.
Image Description:

There is massive swelling of the left submandibular region. The unilateral location and the marked erythema suggest bacterial sialadenitis of the submandibular gland.

E) INCORRECT:

Incision and drainage may be indicated in patients with acute bacterial sialadenitis who develop complications such as a parotid abscess. This patient's presentation, although similar, is inconsistent with a parotid abscess, which is characterized by a subacute onset of symptoms and fluctuation of the parotid gland.
questions.hint: This condition is generally precipitated by a reduction in the flow of saliva (e.g., in postoperative patients).

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of an increasing right-sided cheek swelling for 2 years. He has had recurrent right-sided oral ulcers for the past 2 months. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. He drinks a beer every night. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 71/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 129/83 mm Hg. Examination shows a mild, nontender swelling above the angle of the right jaw. There is no overlying erythema or induration. There are multiple shallow ulcers on the right buccal mucosa and mandibular marginal gingiva. There is no lymphadenopathy. Ultrasound shows a soft tissue mass in the parotid gland. An ultrasound-guided biopsy of the mass confirms the diagnosis of parotid adenoid cystic carcinoma. A right-sided total parotidectomy is scheduled. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following early complications?

choices.text: Hyperesthesia of the right ear lobe
Paralysis of the right lower lip
Impaired taste and sensation of the posterior 1/3 of the tongue
Flushing and sweating of the right cheek while eating

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The sensation of the ear lobe is provided by the greater auricular nerve. Hypoesthesia, not hyperesthesia, of the greater auricular nerve is a common complication of parotidectomy due to nerve transection during surgery.

B) INCORRECT:

Hyperacusis can be a symptom of facial nerve dysfunction (e.g., Bell palsy) due to consequent weakness of the stapedius muscle. The nerve to the stapedius branches off from the facial nerve before the facial nerve exits the skull, which means that stapedius dysfunction cannot be a complication of parotidectomy.

C) INCORRECT:

The parotid gland produces ∼ 40% of the saliva and is stimulated by eating. The total amount of saliva is therefore likely to be slightly decreased after parotidectomy. However, given the continued production of saliva from the remaining salivary glands, xerostomia is not a common complication of the procedure.

D) CORRECT:

Facial nerve palsy is the most common early complication of parotidectomy, and the marginal mandibular branch of the facial nerve, which provides motor control of the lower lip, is one of the most commonly injured branches of the facial nerve. Most cases of post-parotidectomy facial nerve palsy resolve within one month.

Because parotid adenoid cystic carcinomas of the parotid gland grow along nerve sheaths, the facial nerve cannot always be preserved during parotidectomy.
Image Description:

Symptoms in central facial palsy are caused by a contralateral upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion. Because muscles responsible for eyelid and forehead movements are innervated by upper motor neuron fibers from both hemispheres, their function is preserved in central facial palsy. In peripheral facial palsy, damage to lower motor neuron (LMN) fibers results in ipsilateral paralysis of all facial muscles. Because sensory and autonomic fibers join the lower motor neuron fibers of the facial nerve in its peripheral course, peripheral facial palsies can also manifest with non-motoric symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Taste and sensation in the posterior third of the tongue are provided by the glossopharyngeal nerve. Glossopharyngeal nerve damage is not a complication of parotidectomy.

The chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve is responsible for taste of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. However, it joins the facial nerve inside the facial canal (thus inside the skull), which means that chorda tympani dysfunction cannot be a complication of parotidectomy.

F) INCORRECT:

Flushing and sweating of the cheek while eating is characteristic of Frey syndrome, which is a common complication of parotidectomy that results in surgical injury of parasympathetic nerve fibers. However, Frey syndrome manifests late (up to one year after surgery) because of the slow regeneration of the affected parasympathetic fibers and is thus unlikely to cause symptoms earlier than one month after surgery.
questions.hint: The facial nerve runs through the parotid gland and is most likely to be damaged during a total parotidectomy.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman comes to the physician for a 3-month history of gradual swelling on the right side of her face. She has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 18 years. Physical examination shows a right-sided, movable facial mass that is nontender to palpation. There is a visible protrusion of the right lateral wall of the oropharynx. The patient is able to fully open her mouth. There is no cervical lymphadenopathy. Cranial nerves are intact. An MRI shows a 3.3-cm sharply demarcated, lobulated hyperintense mass arising from the right parotid gland. The lesion is surrounded by a hypointense capsule. A biopsy of the mass shows nests of epithelial cells mixed with a chondromyxoid stroma. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common malignant salivary gland tumor and can manifest as a gradually growing, painless unilateral mass arising from the parotid gland. However, malignant salivary gland tumors usually invade into the surrounding tissues and present as a fixed and nonmobile mass, along with cervical lymphadenopathy, facial nerve palsy, and/or trismus, unlike this patient's presentation. Moreover, a biopsy of a mucoepidermoid carcinoma would show an admixture of mucin-producing columnar cells and epidermoid cells, which are not seen here.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a tissue sample from a salivary gland tumor (H&E stain, 200x magnification)

Infiltrative tumor cells with a nested growth pattern in sclerotic stroma can be seen. The tumor cells show two different morphologies. There are mucous cells with bright cytoplasm (examples indicated by green overlay) and intermediate cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm (examples indicated by yellow overlay). The third cell type necessary to confirm the diagnosis (epidermoid cells, which resemble the cells of spinal cell carcinoma) are not depicted here.

B) CORRECT:

A gradually growing, painless, mobile, and well-encapsulated unilateral mass arising from the parotid gland without facial nerve palsy should raise suspicion for a pleomorphic adenoma, the most common benign tumor of the salivary glands. An admixture of epithelial components and chondromyxoid stroma are pathognomonic for pleomorphic adenomas. Because these benign growths have the potential to undergo malignant transformation, complete resection is recommended.

A pleomorphic adenoma can recur if incompletely resected. In a patient with pleomorphic adenoma, rapid enlargement of the mass or the development of facial nerve palsy should raise concern for malignant transformation.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of parotid gland tissue (H&E stain)

On the left, there is a hypercellular area made up of round epithelial cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and narrow, spindle-shaped myoepithelial cells with flattened nuclei. On the right, there is a paucicellular area predominantly made up of hyalinized stroma (pink acellular material).

This mixed pattern of epithelial (epithelial and myoepithelial cells) and mesenchymal (stroma) components within a salivary gland tumor is pathognomonic for pleomorphic adenoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum (Warthin tumor) most commonly occurs among smokers and would present as a gradually growing, painless, mobile, and well-encapsulated mass arising from the parotid gland without facial nerve palsy, which is consistent with this patient's presentation. However, a biopsy of a Warthin tumor would reveal cystic components, abundant lymphocytes, germinal centers, and lymph node-like stroma, which are not seen here.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of parotid gland tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

Cystic structures filled with detritus, lined with a double-layer of cylindrical epithelium and embedded in lymphoid tissue.

This is the typical appearance of Warthin tumor.

D) INCORRECT:

Adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC) can manifest as a gradually growing, painless unilateral mass arising from the parotid gland. However, malignant salivary gland tumors usually invade into the surrounding tissues and present as a fixed and nonmobile mass, along with cervical lymphadenopathy, facial nerve palsy, and/or trismus, unlike this patient's presentation. Moreover, a biopsy of ACC would show an admixture of ductal and myoepithelial cells displaying cribriform, tubular, or solid growth patterns, which are not seen here.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of parotid gland specimen (H&E stain; medium magnification)

Normal parotid tissue with serous acini and intermixed fat tissue is seen on the left quarter of the image. The center and right of the image show tissue of an infiltrating parotid tumor composed of ductal and myoepithelial cells arranged in a gland-like cribriform to tubular, partially cystic (examples indicated by green overlays) architecture. The cystic gland-like structures often contain amphophilic material (examples indicated by asterisks) and feature hyaline stroma interspersed between them (yellow overlay).

This is the typical appearance of adenoid cystic carcinoma.

E) INCORRECT:

A painless and mobile parotid swelling without facial nerve palsy, as seen here, is consistent with granulomatous sialadenitis. However, this condition is characterized by noncaseating granulomatous inflammation (i.e., macrophages, epitheloid cells, and multinucleated giant cells surrounded by lymphocytes), which is not present in this patient.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a parotid gland tissue specimen (H&E stain; 200x magnification)

Salivary gland tissue shows sclerotic changes and fatty degeneration. There is a nonnecrotizing granuloma composed of epitheloid cells and multinucleated giant cells at the center of the image surrounded by a dense lymphocytic infiltrate.

Granulomatous sialadenitis can have various infectious (e.g., mycobacteria, fungi, Bartonella henselae) as well as noninfectious causes (duct obstruction, sarcoidosis).
questions.hint: A well-encapsulated mass, in the absence of signs of tumor invasion into the surrounding tissues (e.g., facial nerve palsy, trismus) or lymphatic spread, suggests a benign lesion of the parotid gland.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of episodic mouth pain. She says the pain begins shortly before meals and subsides within 1–2 hours. She had similar episodes of mouth pain 2 months ago, but they resolved spontaneously. Over-the-counter ibuprofen provided some pain relief. She has no personal or family history of serious illness. Her only medication is a daily multivitamin. She has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 7 years but does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 67/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 119/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a mildly tender, nonerythematous, 1-cm mass in the left submandibular area. Her dentition is normal. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Sialolithiasis typically manifests with tender swelling of a salivary gland and preprandial mouth pain that subsides within 1–2 hours after eating. The anticipation of a meal and the eating process is associated with increased stimulation of the salivary glands and consequent increase in saliva production, which increases the pressure in the obstructed salivary duct and triggers pain. While stones can form in any of the larger salivary glands, approx. 80% of cases occur in the Wharton duct, which is located in the submandibular gland. The diagnosis is usually clinical; imaging may be considered in patients with an unclear diagnosis or suspected salivary gland tumor. Treatment is usually conservative and includes NSAIDs for pain relief as well as salivary gland massage, warm compresses, and hard sour candies for salivary flow stimulation. Patients with sialolithiasis are at increased risk of secondary infection (i.e., acute or chronic sialadenitis) as a consequence of obstruction and consequent salivary stasis.
Image Description:

There is marked swelling of the right submandibular region (arrow). The location of the swelling suggests sialolithiasis of the submandibular gland.

B) INCORRECT:

A mucous retention cyst, also known as a ranula, can manifest with mouth discomfort during meals and swelling of the affected salivary gland. However, ranulas typically affect the sublingual glands and manifest with painless sublingual swelling on the floor of the mouth rather than a tender submandibular mass. Moreover, this condition is not typically associated with preprandial mouth pain.
Image Description:

Floor of the mouth of a 55-year-old patient with an asymmetrical, partially white, partially translucent swelling, which extends above the lower teeth. This finding is a ranula, which is a retention cyst arising in the sublingual gland. It is most commonly seen in patients 10–30 years of age. First-line treatment is the excision of the ranula, including the sublingual gland.

C) INCORRECT:

Pleomorphic adenomas can manifest with unilateral swelling of a salivary gland. However, these tumors typically occur in the parotid rather than submandibular glands and manifest with a painless rather than tender swelling. Moreover, preprandial mouth pain that subsides within 1–2 hours after meals is not a characteristic feature of pleomorphic adenomas.
Image Description:

Photograph of the face of an elderly patient

A significant swelling of the right cheek- and jaw-region can be seen. The location suggests the parotid gland as the cause.

Unilateral swellings of the parotid gland can have several reasons. Sialolithiasis and sialadenitis could be the cause, even though there are no other signs of inflammatory reactions (e.g. erythema). Tumors like pleomorphic adenoma, Warthin's tumor or even carcinoma are plausible too.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute purulent sialadenitis can manifest with unilateral tender swelling of a salivary gland and mouth pain. However, the mouth pain is not typically associated with eating, and the swollen salivary gland is typically erythematous. Moreover, patients commonly present with fever and purulent discharge from the affected gland, none of which are seen here.
Image Description:

There is massive swelling of the left submandibular region. The unilateral location and the marked erythema suggest bacterial sialadenitis of the submandibular gland.

E) INCORRECT:

Sjogren syndrome can manifest with salivary gland swelling and mouth discomfort before and during meals. However, this condition typically manifests with bilateral parotid rather than unilateral mandibular gland swelling. Furthermore, this patient does not have other features of this condition, such as inflammation of the lacrimal glands and sicca syndrome (i.e., dry mouth and eyes).
questions.hint: This patient's smoking history is a risk factor for this condition; other risk factors include dehydration, trauma, and anticholinergic medication.

questions.text:
A 78-year-old man presents with a lump that has developed near his jaw during the past 3 weeks. He is afebrile and has no associated pain or overlying erythema.
Physical examination reveals a palpable, slightly firm, 1.5-cm, left-sided submandibular mass with no cervical or supraclavicular lymphadenopathy. Cranial nerve function is within normal limits.
What is the most appropriate next step in this patient’s care?

choices.text: Increased intake of secretagogues, such as lemon drops and citrus drinks
Epstein-Barr virus and cytomegalovirus serology testing
CT of the head and neck

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Secretagogues are indicated for sialadenitis or salivary stones to encourage salivary flow and are not appropriate for the initial management of a neck mass of unknown etiology. Patients with sialadenitis or salivary stones typically present with pain and swelling in the involved gland.

B) INCORRECT:

Viral infection of the salivary gland with mumps, Epstein-Barr virus, or cytomegalovirus is typically not unilateral.

C) INCORRECT:

Viral infection of the salivary gland with mumps, Epstein-Barr virus, or cytomegalovirus is typically not unilateral.

D) CORRECT:

The differential diagnosis possibilities for salivary swellings are as follows, in order of frequency:

• Benign neoplasms
• Malignancy
• Salivary stones and stenosis
• Salivary swelling (adenosis) secondary to a systemic illness such as Sjögren syndrome or HIV infection

Given the high risk for malignancy (45%–70%), patients with salivary-gland lumps or enlargement (not associated with infection) should be referred for imaging and evaluation by a head and neck surgeon. CT of the head and neck is the best initial approach, as it distinguishes diffuse enlargement from focal masses, characterizes the parenchyma, and allows for evaluation of levels 2 and 3 lymph nodes. Although MRI of the affected area would also be a reasonable option, CT is typically preferred because of its lower cost and greater availability.

If the CT or MRI suggests a need for biopsy, ultrasound can be considered, as it can provide real-time imaging guidance during the biopsy. However, ultrasound will not give as much information as cross-sectional imaging with CT or MRI and is therefore not indicated as first-line imaging.

Key learning point: The most appropriate evaluation for an older adult with a new 1.5-cm submandibular mass that is not erythematous is CT of the head and neck.

E) INCORRECT:

Bacterial infection of a salivary gland is typically associated with erythema, fever, and other features of infection and is most often caused by Staphylococcus aureus, Haemophilus influenzae, or anaerobic organisms of the oral cavity. Antibiotic therapy is inappropriate for a patient without signs of infection.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy presents with a painless mass on the floor of his mouth that has been stable in size for about 6 months. He has had no problems with breathing or swallowing but notes that some speech sounds are distorted.
On examination, he is afebrile and alert and shows no signs of distress. Examination of the oral cavity reveals a 2-cm fluctuant bluish mass on the left floor of the mouth. The remainder of the head and neck examination is normal.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Salivary gland stones (sialolithiasis) occur most often in the submandibular salivary glands. Patients typically present with pain, swelling of the gland, or both. A stone might be palpable under the tongue, or swelling might be present, but it would not be expected to be fluctuant, as in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

Lymphatic malformation is a consideration in this case, but these lesions are typically noted at birth and grow with the child. History often includes fluctuations in size associated with upper respiratory infections.

C) INCORRECT:

Hemangiomas in the oral cavity typically manifest as flat or raised red areas of the mucosa but can also have deep components that give them a bluish appearance. They are typically noted in infants and toddlers during the proliferative phase of development and are therefore less likely than a ranula in this school-age patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Dermoid cysts are true epithelial-lined cysts and are typically filled with keratinous material. They can, on rare occasions, occur on the floor of the mouth, but they tend to be firmer than ranulas and have a yellowish-white appearance rather than the classic blue or clear appearance of a ranula.

E) CORRECT:

This patient most likely has a simple ranula.

Ranulas are true epithelial-lined cysts or pseudocysts that typically result from mucus extravasation caused by traumatic injury to either the acini or the ducts of the sublingual gland. Simple ranulas are limited to the floor of the mouth, whereas plunging ranulas extend through the mylohyoid muscle into the neck. The best treatment for a simple ranula is surgical excision of the ranula and the adjacent sublingual gland.

Key learning point: A bluish fluctuant cystic mass on the floor of the mouth is most likely a ranula.

The condition is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus and typically manifests with sudden swelling of the salivary glands (most often the parotid gland), tenderness, fevers, chills, and secretion of purulent material from the salivary duct, as seen here. In addition to antibiotics, supportive measures like gland massage, hydration, sialogogues, warm compresses, and oral hygiene should be encouraged.

Key learning point: Acute suppurative sialadenitis, most often caused by Staphylococcus aureus, is treated with antibiotics such as amoxicillin/clavulanate and supportive care measures.
Image Description:

There is massive swelling of the left submandibular region. The unilateral location and the marked erythema suggest bacterial sialadenitis of the submandibular gland.

C) INCORRECT:

A parotid biopsy is indicated if a parotid neoplasm is suspected. Although parotid tumors can also cause swelling of the gland, they are usually painless and have a much slower course (typically over months) than this patient's symptoms. Associated symptoms due to the infiltration of neighboring structures (e.g., the facial nerve) are common in patients with parotid neoplasms, while purulent discharge and fever as in this patient are rare.

D) INCORRECT:

Parotidectomy is used in the treatment of parotid neoplasms, salivary duct stones, and as a last resort in patients with recurrent infections of the parotid gland. This patient is only experiencing her first episode of sialadenitis. Additionally, she has no history of any conditions that would put her at risk for recurrent infections (e.g., diabetes mellitus).

E) INCORRECT:

Sialoendoscopy may be indicated in patients with recurrent sialolithiasis, which can also cause bacterial sialadenitis as in this patient. However, this is the patient's first episode of sialadenitis and the absence of calculi in the salivary duct on oral examination makes this etiology less likely. Sialoendoscopy is not the treatment of choice for suppurative sialadenitis if it is not caused by sialolithiasis.
questions.hint: This condition is generally precipitated by a reduction in the flow of saliva (e.g., in postoperative patients).

questions.text: A 78-year-old man comes to your clinic with a lump near his jaw that has developed over the past 3 weeks. He has no fever, pain, or overlying erythema. On examination, you find a palpable, slightly firm, 1.5-cm left-sided submandibular mass without cervical or supraclavicular lymphadenopathy. Cranial nerve function is normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Epstein-Barr virus and cytomegalovirus serology testing.
CT of the head and neck.
Increased intake of secretagogues, such as lemon drops and citrus drinks.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Viral infection of the salivary gland with Epstein-Barr virus or cytomegalovirus is typically not unilateral.

B) CORRECT:

The differential diagnosis possibilities for salivary swellings are as follows, in order of frequency:

• Benign neoplasms
• Malignancy
• Salivary stones and stenosis
• Salivary swelling (adenosis) secondary to a systemic illness such as Sjögren syndrome or HIV infection

Given the high risk for malignancy (45%–70%), patients with salivary-gland lumps or enlargement (not associated with infection) should be referred for imaging and evaluation by a head and neck surgeon. CT of the head and neck is the best initial approach, as it distinguishes diffuse enlargement from focal masses, characterizes the parenchyma, and allows for evaluation of levels 2 and 3 lymph nodes. Although MRI of the affected area would also be a reasonable option, CT is typically preferred because of its lower cost and greater availability.

If the CT or MRI suggests a need for biopsy, ultrasound can be considered, as it can provide real-time imaging guidance during the biopsy. However, ultrasound will not give as much information as cross-sectional imaging with CT or MRI and is therefore not indicated as first-line imaging.

Key learning point: The most appropriate evaluation for an older adult with a new 1.5-cm submandibular mass that is not erythematous is CT of the head and neck.

C) INCORRECT:

Viral infection of the salivary gland with mumps is typically not unilateral.

D) INCORRECT:

Secretagogues are indicated for sialadenitis or salivary stones to encourage salivary flow and are not appropriate for the initial management of a neck mass of unknown etiology. Patients with sialadenitis or salivary stones typically present with pain and swelling in the involved gland.

E) INCORRECT:

Bacterial infection of a salivary gland is typically associated with erythema, fever, and other features of infection and is most often caused by Staphylococcus aureus, Haemophilus influenzae, or anaerobic organisms of the oral cavity. Antibiotic therapy is inappropriate for a patient without signs of infection.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-week history of episodic mouth pain. She reports that the pain starts shortly before meals and resolves within 1–2 hours. She had similar episodes 2 months ago that resolved on their own. She has a 7-year history of smoking half a pack of cigarettes daily. On examination, there is a mildly tender, nonerythematous, 1-cm mass in the left submandibular area. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute purulent sialadenitis can manifest with unilateral tender swelling of a salivary gland and mouth pain. However, the mouth pain is not typically associated with eating, and the swollen salivary gland is typically erythematous. Moreover, patients commonly present with fever and purulent discharge from the affected gland.

B) INCORRECT:

Pleomorphic adenomas can manifest with unilateral swelling of a salivary gland. However, these tumors typically occur in the parotid rather than submandibular glands and manifest with a painless rather than tender swelling. Moreover, preprandial mouth pain that subsides within 1–2 hours after meals is not a characteristic feature of pleomorphic adenomas.

C) CORRECT:

Sialolithiasis typically manifests with tender swelling of a salivary gland and preprandial mouth pain that subsides within 1–2 hours after eating. The anticipation of a meal and the eating process is associated with increased stimulation of the salivary glands and consequent increase in saliva production, which increases the pressure in the obstructed salivary duct and triggers pain. While stones can form in any of the larger salivary glands, approx. 80% of cases occur in the Wharton duct, which is located in the submandibular gland. The diagnosis is usually clinical; imaging may be considered in patients with an unclear diagnosis or suspected salivary gland tumor. Treatment is usually conservative and includes NSAIDs for pain relief as well as salivary gland massage, warm compresses, and hard sour candies for salivary flow stimulation. Patients with sialolithiasis are at increased risk of secondary infection (i.e., acute or chronic sialadenitis) as a consequence of obstruction and consequent salivary stasis.

Key learning point: Sialolithiasis presents as preprandial mouth pain and tender swelling of a salivary gland, most commonly the submandibular gland, due to obstruction by a salivary stone.
Image Description:

There is marked swelling of the right submandibular region (arrow). The location of the swelling suggests sialolithiasis of the submandibular gland.

D) INCORRECT:

A mucous retention cyst, also known as a ranula, can manifest with mouth discomfort during meals and swelling of the affected salivary gland. However, ranulas typically affect the sublingual glands and manifest with painless sublingual swelling on the floor of the mouth rather than a tender submandibular mass. Moreover, this condition is not typically associated with preprandial mouth pain.

E) INCORRECT:

Sjogren syndrome can manifest with salivary gland swelling and mouth discomfort before and during meals. However, this condition typically manifests with bilateral parotid rather than unilateral mandibular gland swelling. Furthermore, this patient does not have other features of this condition, such as inflammation of the lacrimal glands and sicca syndrome (i.e., dry mouth and eyes).
questions.hint: This patient's smoking history is a risk factor for this condition; other risk factors include dehydration, trauma, and anticholinergic medication.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a 2-day history of right submandibular swelling and pain that worsens when eating. There is no history of fever, chills, or oral discharge. Physical examination of the swollen area shown reveals tenderness but no warmth. Vital signs are normal. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While CT without contrast is the first-line imaging for detecting salivary stones with high sensitivity, imaging is not necessary in this patient. Sialolithiasis is primarily a clinical diagnosis based on characteristic postprandial pain and swelling. Conservative symptomatic management should be attempted first, as many stones pass spontaneously. CT imaging is reserved for when conservative management is unsuccessful or complications are suspected.

B) INCORRECT:

Incision and drainage are indicated for abscesses complicating acute suppurative sialadenitis, which manifests with purulent discharge, erythema, warmth, and fever. This patient has classic uncomplicated sialolithiasis with postprandial symptoms but no signs of infection (fever, erythema, warmth, or purulent discharge). The absence of inflammatory signs makes abscess formation unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Antibiotics are indicated for acute suppurative sialadenitis, characterized by purulent discharge from the salivary duct, erythema, warmth, and systemic symptoms such as fever. This patient does not have the characteristic features of bacterial infection and presents with mechanical obstruction from sialolithiasis rather than bacterial sialadenitis, making antibiotics unnecessary.

D) INCORRECT:

Otolaryngology consultation is indicated for stones within the gland or proximal duct, stones > 5 mm, recurrent episodes, symptoms lasting more than a few days despite conservative treatment, or insufficient response to antibiotic therapy for suppurative sialadenitis. This patient has a 2-day history without previous episodes, making initial conservative management appropriate before specialist referral.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- Conservative management with sialogogues and NSAIDs is the first-line treatment for uncomplicated sialolithiasis. Sialogogues (e.g., lemon drops, sugar-free gum) increase salivary flow, creating hydrostatic pressure that may mobilize small stones while reducing infection risk. NSAIDs provide pain relief and reduce inflammation and ductal edema. This approach, combined with hydration and warm compresses, is usually effective for managing uncomplicated sialolithiasis without invasive intervention.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with diabetes mellitus presents with a 3-day history of progressive left-sided facial swelling and pain that worsens with eating. Vital signs are P, 98; BP, 138/64; T, 38.9°C (102.0°F). Physical examination of the face is shown. There is no fluctuance, and gentle massage of the swollen area produces thick discharge inside the mouth. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Supportive care with sialagogues alone is insufficient for acute suppurative sialadenitis. While sialagogues may be used as adjunctive therapy to promote saliva flow, purulent discharge and systemic symptoms require targeted treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Prednisone is not indicated for acute suppurative sialadenitis. Corticosteroids would be inappropriate for a bacterial infection and could potentially worsen the condition by suppressing the immune response.

C) INCORRECT:

Incision and drainage is reserved for patients with abscesses. This patient has acute suppurative sialadenitis but no evidence of abscess formation that would require surgical intervention as the initial management.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has acute suppurative sialadenitis based on the unilateral parotid swelling, purulent discharge, fever, and risk factors (diabetes mellitus). The thick discharge indicates bacterial infection requiring antibiotic therapy. Appropriate first-line antibiotics for acute suppurative sialadenitis include clindamycin or amoxicillin/clavulanate.

E) INCORRECT:

Sialoendoscopy is used for stone extraction in patients with sialolithiasis or may be considered in chronic sialadenitis if conservative management is ineffective. Acute suppurative sialadenitis requires antibiotic therapy as the initial treatment.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with diabetes mellitus presents with a 4-day history of left-sided jaw pain and swelling that worsens when eating. She appears unwell with a temperature of 38.9°C (102.0°F). Physical examination shows firm, fluctuant swelling, with induration extending to the neck. Gentle pressure over the area produces thick, cloudy discharge inside the mouth. Laboratory results show leukocytosis with left shift. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Order mumps titers and initiate isolation precautions
Initiate hydration and sialagogue therapy with antibiotics

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The presence of purulent discharge and unilateral involvement in an older adult with systemic symptoms strongly suggests a bacterial rather than viral cause. Mumps typically causes bilateral swelling and occurs in younger, unvaccinated individuals.

B) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids are contraindicated in bacterial sialadenitis because they can worsen the infection. While analgesics provide symptomatic relief, they do not address the underlying bacterial infection or potential complications.

C) INCORRECT:

While hydration, sialagogues, and antibiotics are appropriate initial management for uncomplicated acute suppurative sialadenitis, the fluctuant swelling and extension to the neck suggest possible abscess formation, which requires imaging evaluation before initiating treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

While otolaryngology consultation may be needed for surgical drainage if an abscess is confirmed, imaging should be obtained first to characterize the extent of disease and assess for complications.

E) CORRECT:

Correct --The fluctuant swelling and extension of induration to the neck raises concern for abscess formation, which is a complication of acute suppurative sialadenitis. CT imaging is indicated when there is concern for complications such as abscess, and should be obtained before initiating treatment to guide appropriate management.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with a 3-week history of progressive left parotid swelling. Physical examination shows a 3-cm firm, fixed mass with overlying skin dimpling. She reports new difficulty closing her left eye completely and that the left corner of her mouth droops when she smiles. The patient has no pain, fever, or recent dental problems. Which finding most strongly suggests malignancy?

choices.text: Inability to close the eye completely
Firm, fixed consistency of the mass

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Inability to close the eye completely indicates facial nerve involvement, which is a strong clinical criterion for malignancy in salivary gland tumors. Facial palsy caused by infiltration of neighboring structures is characteristic of malignant salivary gland tumors and requires urgent evaluation.

B) INCORRECT:

While firm, fixed masses can suggest malignancy, they are not specific. Benign pleomorphic adenomas can also manifest as firm masses. This finding alone is insufficient to determine whether the tumor is malignant.

C) INCORRECT:

Overlying skin changes such as dimpling can occur with both benign and malignant salivary gland tumors, particularly when masses are large or deep. This is not the most specific indicator of malignancy.

D) INCORRECT:

Painless presentation is characteristic of both benign and malignant salivary gland tumors. The absence of pain does not help differentiate between benign and malignant tumor.

E) INCORRECT:

Progressive growth over weeks can occur with both benign and malignant salivary gland tumors. The timeframe alone does not distinguish between the two types of masses.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with acute-onset left-sided facial swelling and pain that began yesterday. She reports three similar episodes over the past 8 months, each resolving with antibiotics. She appears ill and reports nausea and difficulty swallowing. Vital signs are T, 39.1°C (102.4°F); P, 110. Physical examination shows a firm, tender submandibular gland with purulent discharge from Wharton duct. CT scan shows a 6-mm stone in the proximal left submandibular duct. What is the most appropriate disposition?

choices.text: Discharge home with oral antibiotics and emergency department return precautions
Discharge home with oral antibiotics and primary care follow-up in 1 week
Admission for IV antibiotics with otolaryngology consultation if no improvement in 48 hours
Admission for IV antibiotics and urgent otolaryngology consultation
Discharge home with oral antibiotics and otolaryngology follow-up within 48 hours

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The patient's ill appearance, high fever, nausea, and difficulty swallowing indicate severe infection that would not be adequately managed with outpatient oral antibiotics. Additionally, emergency department return precautions do not address the need for surgical management of the underlying sialolithiasis with recurrent episodes and a proximal stone > 5 mm.

B) INCORRECT:

Primary care follow-up alone is insufficient; recurrent sialolithiasis with a proximal stone > 5 mm requires otolaryngology consultation for definitive management. Furthermore, the patient's severe presentation with high fever, tachycardia, and systemic symptoms would not be adequately managed with outpatient oral antibiotics.

C) INCORRECT:

While inpatient IV antibiotics are required due to the severe infection, delaying otolaryngology consultation is inappropriate. There are clear indications for immediate surgical consultation: recurrent episodes, proximal stone > 5 mm, and acute suppurative sialadenitis with systemic symptoms.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient meets multiple criteria for urgent otolaryngology consultation: recurrent sialolithiasis, stone > 5 mm, proximal duct location, and acute suppurative sialadenitis. Ill appearance, high fever, tachycardia, nausea, and difficulty swallowing indicate severe infection requiring inpatient IV antibiotic therapy along with consultation for definitive management.

E) INCORRECT:

While otolaryngology consultation is required, this disposition does not address the severity of this patient's condition. Ill appearance, high fever, nausea, difficulty swallowing, and tachycardia indicate severe infection that would not be adequately managed with outpatient antibiotics.
